stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on modeling and texturing the main tower for Course 11, collaborating live with Biobak to implement a new, animated power meter and a Bowser logo. He also showcased significant reworks of older levels, discussed his design philosophies, and shared personal anecdotes with his wife, Zeina.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 has been tentatively named 'Oily Boily Bay'. Kaze chose this goofy name over more serious suggestions because he finds it fun and memorable.
development_findings.quote: Oily Boily Bay, you know what, I'm gonna just set that as a temporary name. I think it's a pretty stupid name, but I still kinda like it.

development_findings.summary: The camera controls have been completely overhauled to be more responsive, with C-left/right now providing instant rotation and the D-pad offering slow rotation, a change made in response to feedback about input lag.

A new power/breath meter, designed by Biobak, was implemented. Kaze added smooth scaling animations for its appearance and a progressive fill effect using an alpha threshold technique on a gradient texture.
A new collectible feature is being added based on a dream Kaze had. Players will be able to find three hidden Toads in the overworlds, and finding them all will unlock a special song.
development_findings.quote: In my dream I had put four totes over my game and they won't all play an instrument very poorly... And you know what? I'm kinda doing this.

development_findings.summary: Many levels from the public demo, such as the retro section in Course 2, have been completely reworked to improve gameplay, camera behavior, and visual quality.
Kaze is considering using a two-week vacation from his job to implement a split-screen multiplayer mode for the game.
Kaze was informed about a new microcode that can disable near clipping, which he believes could solve some of the game's camera issues.

Kaze is aware that a new quaternion system from Lilaa could enable smoother animation transitions (e.g., idle to run), but he is hesitant to implement it because he prioritizes 'snappy' and responsive controls.
development_findings.quote: I think I won't make it Mario's movement less snappy so I don't really want that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a full-time job as a programmer at a video game company, which he took because ROM hacking does not pay the bills. This significantly impacts his time for the project.
context_findings.quote: ROM making is not that lucrative, so I had to get a job other than that. And that is keeping me very busy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states he is willing to work 70-hour weeks combining his day job and ROM hacking, indicating an intense work ethic and dedication.
context_findings.quote: I don't mind working 70-hour weeks. I'm kind of just a little different.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design principle against including 'memes' in his game, aiming to create a project with lasting quality and personal meaning rather than fleeting humor.
context_findings.quote: This is a game, not a meme. You might say I'm stuck up for actually making sure that my game is not just a meme, but this is what I want in my life. I want a game that keeps me occupied for the long term.

context_findings.summary: Kaze places high importance on color theory and ensuring the game's color palettes are aesthetically pleasing and cohesive, as demonstrated by his detailed discussion about the power meter colors with Biobak.
context_findings.quote: I care a lot about making the colors work together in a way that is satisfying.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong negative opinion of Super Mario Sunshine, calling it the game that 'hurt him the most', which suggests its design may influence his own work as a counterexample.
context_findings.quote: It's maybe it's not the worst game. But it's the game that hurt me the most.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals that Mario 64 is such a fundamental part of his life that he uses its release as a mental milestone for judging a person's age and experiences.
context_findings.quote: I do categorize people into being born before and after Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina rescued a baby bird, nursed it back to health, and released it. This personal story was shared by both of them on stream.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed the new sprites for the power/health meter and collaborated with Kaze live on stream to refine the color palette to prevent unwanted brightness shifts.
Biobak created a new Bowser logo for the tower in Course 11 after Kaze requested one.
Biobak actively participates in the stream chat, reminding Kaze about the health meter assets and providing feedback and suggestions in real-time.
biobak.quote: What about health meter, Mr. Case?

zeina.summary: Zeina banters with Kaze about his intense work habits, joking that she would leave to visit her parents if he went on a marathon streaming session during his vacation.
zeina.quote: I'll just go visit my parents if you're gonna do the eight-hour stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina engages in playful banter with Kaze about their personal life, including his cooking skills, providing a glimpse into their relationship dynamic as both partners and collaborators.
zeina.quote: I've been saying you can't cook since I married you.

zeina.summary: Zeina co-narrated the story of rescuing a baby bird, adding details to Kaze's account.

key_stories.title: The New Power Meter
key_stories.summary: Biobak designed a new power meter, leading to a live collaboration with Kaze to perfect its color palette. Kaze then implemented it, adding custom animations that improved the game's overall polish, demonstrating their effective teamwork and attention to detail.
key_stories.challenge: The existing UI elements were outdated, and the team needed a new, polished power/breath meter with a color scheme that worked well visually without jarring shifts in brightness.
key_stories.process: Biobak designed the new meter sprites. He and Kaze collaborated live on stream to adjust the color palette, specifically to manage the perceived brightness difference between blue and green. Kaze then implemented the asset and coded new scaling and smooth-fill animations.
key_stories.outcome: A new, professionally designed power meter is now in the game. It features a carefully considered color palette and smooth animations for appearing and filling, showcasing the team's high standards and collaborative process.
key_stories.key_quote: Me and Biobak, we went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right. Because I didn't want the brightness to increase from blue to green.

key_stories.title: Naming 'Oily Boily Bay'
key_stories.summary: While trying to name the new oil rig level, Kaze and his community went through several suggestions. Kaze ultimately latched onto the silly name 'Oily Boily Bay' because it was memorable and fun, establishing it as the working title.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a suitable, catchy name for the new oil rig level (Course 11) that fits the game's style.
key_stories.process: Kaze and the community brainstormed names for the level. After several more conventional suggestions, the name 'Oily Boily Bay' was proposed. Kaze immediately liked its goofy, rhythmic quality and adopted it as the working title.
key_stories.outcome: The level was tentatively named 'Oily Boily Bay'. The name, while silly, was chosen for being memorable and fun to say, setting a high bar for any future suggestions and revealing Kaze's preference for fun over pure seriousness.
key_stories.key_quote: Oily Boily Bay is so goofy, but it works. Kinda, yeah.

key_stories.title: The Accidental Toad Feature
key_stories.summary: Kaze had a strange dream about Toads playing instruments poorly. He found the concept so amusing that he decided to turn it into a real in-game feature, creating a new side-quest where players find hidden Toads to unlock a musical reward.
key_stories.challenge: Coming up with unique side content and collectibles to enrich the game world.
key_stories.process: The idea originated entirely from a bizarre dream Kaze had. He shared the dream on stream and immediately decided to adapt a version of it into a real, implementable feature for the game.
key_stories.outcome: A new feature is planned where players can find three hidden Toads across the overworlds. Finding them all will result in them playing a special song, adding a unique exploratory side-quest to the game.
key_stories.key_quote: In my dream I had put four totes over my game and they won't all play an instrument very poorly... And you know what? I'm kinda doing this.
